coredata.dc:title: Alkali co-adsorption and surface coverage effects on electron-stimulated desorption (ESD): CO and NO on Ni(111)
coredata.dc:creator: Bozso, F.
Avouris, Ph.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
We present results on the effect of potassium co-adsorption on the ESD from CO and NO on Ni(111) at 90 K. K co-adsorption strongly affects the yields of positive ions and alters their electron beam energy dependence. At a K-coverage of θK = 0.25 and saturation coverages of CO or NO, the strong O+ ESD threshold associated with O 1s ionization is eliminated. We attribute this to increased metal → CO(2π★) electron back-donation upon K addition which screens the O 1s hole, and reduces the excitation probability of shake-off/shake-up processes responsible for O+ ESD. For fixed K-coverage, the ESD yields depend on adsorbate coverage. For θK = 0.25 and CO or NO exposures <1 L the adsorbate state is ESD inactive at both valence- and core-excitation energies.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 125, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 18 April 1986 ALKALI CO-ADSORPTION AND SURFACE COVERAGE EFFECTS ON ELECTRON-STIMULATED DESORPTION (ESD): CO AND NO ON Ni(lll) F. BOZSO and Ph. AVOURIS IBM T.J. Watson Research Center. P.O. Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, USA Received 12 December 1985; in final form 27 January 1986 We present results on the effect of potassium co-adsorption on the BSD from CO and NO on Ni(lll) at 90 K. K co-adsorption strongly affects the yields of positive ions and alters their electron beam energy dependence. At a K-coverage of SK = 0.25 and saturation coverages of CO or NO, the strong O4' ESD threshold associated with 0 Is ionization is eliminated. We attribute this to increased metal -> C0(2w*) electron back-donation upon K addition which screens the 0 Is hole, and reduces the excitation probability of shake-off/shake-up processes responsible for 0+ ESD. For fixed K-coverage, the ESD yields depend on adsorbate coverage. For 9^ = 0.25 and CO or NO exposures < 1 L the adsorbate state is ESD inactive at both valence- and core-excitation energies. 1. Introduction Recently, considerable attention has been focused on the effects of "surface modifiers" such as akali metals or electronegative elements on the chemisorp- tion of prototype systems, such as CO or NO on tran- sition metals. Rather dramatic modifications of the ground state chemistry of such systems have been ob- served [1]. Here we show that co-adsorption can induce equal- ly dramatic changes in excited state surface chemistry. We present results on the effects of K co-adsorption, and varying adsorbate surface coverage on the yields of ions desorbed as a result of electron-beam excita- tion of CO and NO on Ni(l 11). We find that the ion yields and their dependence on electron beam energy are strongly affected. In particular, K co-adsorption appears to eliminate 0"*' ion desorption paths associated with Ols ionization, while, at least at high adsorbate coverages, processes initiated by valence excitations are affected to a lesser extent. Our electron-stimulated desorption experiments provide evidence suggesting that a strongly perturbed adsorbate state is formed at low adsorbate exposures to the K-modified surface. Possible explanations for the observed excited state behavior are discussed on the basis of schemes pro- 0 009-2614/86/$ 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) posed to account for the effect of alkali co-adsorption on the ground state of the above systems. 2. Experimental The experiments described in this study were per- formed in a UHV chamber with a 2 X 10"~10 Torr working pressure. The chamber was equipped with an X-ray photoemission spectrometer, a quadrupole mass spectrometer, and low-energy electron diffrac- tion. The Ni(l 11) single crystal was cleaned by a treat- ment consisting of heating cyclically the crystal to 1200 K in 10-7 Torr oxygen and prolonged argon ion bombardment. The potassium was deposited from an SAES getter source at 90 K, and a 6^ = 0.25 coverage was established by a standardized partial thermal de- sorption process. The electron beam current in the electron-stimulated desorption experiments was between 20 200 nA focused to a surface area of 10 mm2. 3. Results and discussion In fig. 1 we show the electron beam energy depen- dence ( g) of the CO^, 0'*' and O2'1" ion yields from a 531 Volume 125, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 18 ApiU 1986 200 400 600 0 200 400 600 ELECTRON BEAM ENERGY (eV) Fig. 1. (a) Electron beam energy (Ey) dependence of the O* and CO'1' ESD signals from CO/Ni(l 11) at 90 K. (b) The Ey dependence of the ESD signals upon co-adsorption of 0.25 monolayer, p(2 X 2), of potassium, (c) The Ey, dependence of the ESD yields in the presence of 0.25 monolayer of oxy- gen. (d) Ey dependence of the O* and 02* ESD signals from 02/Ni(lll)at90K. saturated monolayer of CO on clean and modified Ni(l 11). On the clean surface (fig. 1A), the O"*" and CO"*" yields show energy thresholds in the valence region ( g < 30 eV), rise to a very broad maximum in the vicinity of 250 eV and then, while the CO* yield decreases, the O'1" yield shows another strong threshold at 570 eV, i.e. about 30 eV above to 0 K-edge energy which we measure by XPS. These observations are in agreement with previous ESD studies on similar sys- tems, e.g., CO/Ru(001) [2,3] and CO/W(110) [4]. When potassium is added to form a p(2 X 2) overlayer (surface coverage, 0^ = 0.25), as is shown in fig. 1B, the CO'*" yield is strongly reduced (X50), and while no drastic changes are observed in the valence region, the O"1" threshold in the vicinity of the 0 K-edge is totally eliminated. To test the possibility that fig. 1B represents the ESD yield of dissociated CO, we have determined the O"1" yield from an oxygen-exposed Ni(l 11) surface which is shown in fig. ID. An 0 K-edge related threshold is also present in this case. Thermal desorption spectroscopy (TDS) shows that the great majority of CO desorbs at w450 K from the clean surface, in agreement with previous reports [5], while CO from the K-modified surface desorbs at 630 K. The increased desorption temperature is in line with the expected increased metal CO bond energy upon K addition. In fig. 1C, we show the ESD behavior of CO on Ni(l 11) modified by pre-adsorbing oxygen (OQ = 0.25). All positive ion yields are high, O2"1" ions are easily detected, and both the O"1" and O2"*" ions show an 0 K-edge related ESD threshold. 200 400 600 800 0 200 400 600 800 ELECTRON BEAM ENERGY (eV) Fig. 2. (a) Electron beam energy ( g) dependence of the ESD yields of positive ions from NO/Ni(lll) at 90 K. (b) The Ey dependence upon co-adsorption of 0.25 monolayer of potas- In fig. 2 we show ESD results for NO/Ni(l 11) and NO + K/Ni(l 11) obtained at 90 K. At this temperature we find that NO is molecularly adsorbed on the Ni(l 11) surface as is evidenced by our XPS studies which show N IsandO lsbindingenergiesof400.2and530.9eV, respectively. These values are characteristic ofundis- sociated ("virgin") NO [6]. The NO remains molecu- larly adsorbed on the K-modified surface, at 90 K the N Is binding energy is 1.8 eV higher than that of atomic nitrogen on this modified Ni surface. As can be seen from fig. 2A the energy dependence of the NO'1" and O"*" yields from NO on clean Ni(l 11) is sim- ilar to those of CO"1" and 0"^ from the CO-covered surface. Both the O"1" and O2"1" yields show a sharp increase in the vicinity of the 0 K-edge. No such in- crease is observed at the N K-edge or at the Ni 2p-edge (not shown). Potassium modification of the surface (fig. 2B) renders the NO"1" and O2"*" unobservable at our detection sensitivity and, as in the case of CO, the Ols ionization-related enhancement of the O"1" yield is absent. The inactivation of the core-ionization-related ESD paths by alkali co-adsorption is a novel and interest- ing effect. In attempting to interpret this effect we realize that, in principle, the co-adsorption can affect the desorption process by either modifying the pre- cursor excited state leading to the particular desorp- tion product and/or modifying the neutralization yield of the ionic product. If the ion is produced with dif- ferent kinetic energy in the two cases and thus has different interaction times with the modified surface, 532 Volume 125, numba" 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 18 April 1986 the surface modifier can produce a different neutraliza- tion yield of the O'1" ion produced by different mech- anisms, i.e. by valence and core excitations. However, we do not find significant differences in the kinetic energy distribution of O"1' produced with Ey below or above the 0 K-edge. In both cases, the peak of the kinetic energy distribution lies at ^7 eV. Thus, we have to investigate the possible effects of the modifier on the precursor excited/ionic state itself. The mech- anisms of ESD/PSD are still a matter of debate but some crystallization of ideas has become possible re- cently. The thresholds for CO"1' and 0"'" desorption from CO on transition metals are usually associated with the onset of ionization from, respectively, the So and 3cr levels of chemisorbed CO at 15 and ^30 eV [2]. Cluster model calculations [7] support this conclusion. Core ionization in itself may lead to bound states [8] but their subsequent Auger decay could lead to desorption. However, experiments on chemisorbed CO indicate that C Is ionization has little [2] or no effect [4] on the CO"1' yield and no effect [2,4] on the O'1" yield, in agreement with our findings here. Synchrotron PSD studies have shown that CO 0 Is-ionization or 0 Is -> 2-n* excitation do no lead to an increase in the O4" yield either, but rather the enhancement threshold is 30 eV above the 0 K-edge [9]. This threshold has been ascribed to a "shake-off" transition, i.e. the simultaneous ejec- tion of a core electron and a valence electron to give the 0 1s-13o-1 two-hole (2h) state [9]. Chemisorbed NO appears to behave in a way analogous to CO. It is believed that the mechanism by which alkali metal addition affects the chemisorption of ground state CO involves an enhancement of the metal - C0(27r*) back-donation. This enhanced back-donation increases the strength of the M C bond while decreas- ing the strength of the C-0 bond [10]. A different model stresses a rehybridization of the C atom from sp, in free CO, to sp2 to give a formaldehyde-like car- bonyl species on the metal surface [11]. Specific interactions between the CO and adjacent alkali ions on the metal surface have been suggested [12]. Thus, we have to consider the possible consequences of enhanced back-donation and rehybridization on the O"1" BSD yields. As was mentioned earlier, the main path for O"*" desorption via core excitation involves the 2h 0 Is-^So-1 state produced by a shake-off process [9]. This shake-off process proceeds via a monopole excitation mechanism, the direct result of the response (relaxation) of the valence levels to the creation of the core hole. It is also established that the main screening mechanism of core holes in chemisorbed CO involves charge transfer of a metal electron to the 2-n* level of CO (13]. This level is only slightly occupied in the neutral ground state of the system but in the presence of the core hole its binding energy is increased and the level is occupied by a screening metal electron. Alkali co-adsorption increases the amount of ff-charge back-donation to the 2ff* level in the ground state of the system. The ex- tent of this donation is not known but it is expected to be large. Thus, for example, NEXAFS experiments on CO on Pt(l 11) + Na indicate an elongation of the C-0 bond by 0.12 0.03 A [14]. This is a dramatic effect since the theoretically computed [15] change in R(C-0) on going from free CO to CO" is 0.11 A. If a large ground state 2v* occupation is achieved upon K co-adsorption, then the umelaxed state pro- duced upon core ionization on that surface will look very similar to the relaxed (screened) core-hole state formed in the absence of K co-adsorption. The in- creased screening of the core-hole potential by the charge in the 2?r* level would reduce relaxation effects and thus reduce the probability of monopole-excited shake-off/shake-up processes leading to ESD. A fully screened 0 Is hole state is very similar to the 0 Is -> lv* neutral excited state [8] which, as we mentioned earlier, does not lead to an enhancement of the 0"*" yield [9]. In the valence region, on the other hand, multi-electron excitations important in BSD are pro- duced as a result of configuration interaction mixing with single-particle excited states. The mixing is due to electron correlation not relaxation effects. This is the case, for example, of the 3o~1 state which is CI- coupled to 2hle excitations [16]. Accepting the notion that the shake-off process is essentially atomic in nature [16] and within the adia- batic approximation one can obtain approximate shake-off probabilities from a particular molecular or- bital (MO) using the net atomic populations of the MO at the atom with the core-hole, and the correspond- ing atomic shake-off probabilities [16]. A very rough estimate of the effect of rehybridization on the shake- off probability can be obtained by using formaldehyde as a model for the sp^hybridized surface carbonyl. An SCF calculation along these lines shows no differ- 533 Volume 125, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 18 April 1986 CO K/Nl(lll) 9^0.25,90 K Ee 400eV (b) 01230123 CO EXPOSURE (LANGMUIR) Fig. 3. (a) Top: the CO exposure, in langmuir, dependence of the O* ESD yield from an ordered Ni(lll) surface at 90 K using an electron beam energy, "e = 400 eV, i.e. below the 0 K-edge. Middle: the exposure dependence after the ?(111) has been sputtered with AT* and exposed to CO without previously annealing the damage, Ey = 400 eV. Bottom: the CO exposure dependence of ESD from an ordered Ni(lll) surface with Es = 1000 eV, i.e. above the 0 K-edge. (b) The CO exposure dependence of the O* yield in the presence of 0.25 monolayer, p(2 X 2), potassium, Ey = 400 eV. ence in the 3a shake-off probabilities of the two hy- bridized forms [17]. This suggests that re-hybridiza- tion is not important in determining the shake-off process. However, any definite conclusion on this point should await more rigorous calculations employ- ing more realistic models for the surface species. Up to this point, we have discussed ESD from satu- rated CO or NO layers. In this section, we explore the adsorbate surface coverage dependence of the ESD and the effect of K co-adsorption on this dependence. In fig. 3awe show the CO-exposure dependence of the O"1" yield from CO on clean Ni(l 11). The top curve gives this dependence for g = 400 eV, that is at an energy below the 0 K-edge. As has been reported earlier [5], the 0"*" yield rises steeply at low exposures to a maximum value at around 1.2-1.5 L and then de- creases and levels off after saturation. We find that this behavior is sensitive to the e-beam energy and that the observed quenching of the 0+ ESD yield is less pronounced at energies above the 0 K-edge, as can be seen from the bottom curve obtained at Eg = 1 keV. This observation suggests that valence-excited pre- cursors of the O4' are preferentially affected by the increased surface coverage. The ESD behavior is also affected by the presence of defects, as is shown in the second curve which was obtained by sputtering the Ni(l 11) with Ar"1" and then exposing it to CO without annealing the damage. Two effects are observed: (a) the ESD intensity is increased, and (b) the coverage- dependent quenching is decreased even for fg in the valence region. The coverage-dependent ESD yield may be due to changes in binding site or lateral inter- actions. Since no changes in binding site take place in the exposure range where the changes in the 0"'" yield are observed [5], it is most likely to be charge delo- calization in the adsorbate layer via resonance charge exchange [5] that is responsible for the observed be- havior. The more diffuse valence-excited/ionized states will be more affected than the localized core states by these lateral interactions. Defects and disorder can en- hance the ESD yield by breaking the resonance condi- tion for charge transfer and possibly providing sites of low coordination and thus reduced ion re-neutral- ization rate. In fig. 3b we show the CO coverage dependence of the 0"'" yield from the K-modified surface. Coverage- dependent ESD is again present. However, unlike the case of the unmodified Ni surface, K co-adsorption leads to a delayed onset of the 0"*" ESD yield versus coverage. Parallel desorption studies indicate that this delay is not due to a reduced sticking coefficient. Thus, the delayed onset must be due to the nature of the initially adsorbed CO which may be closely associated with the K atoms on the Ni surface. A special state of chemisorbed CO was observed by EELS at low CO coverages in CO+K/Ru(001) [18].This state is charac- terized by a very low vibrational frequency and has been ascribed to flat-lying or tilted CO. The delayed onset seen in fig. 3b can be explained by an initial for- mation of such a tilted phase of chemisorbed CO. Besides possible modification of ESD due to electronic structure differences, image effecs on the 0"'" trajec- tory from tilted CO may lead to efficient neutraliza- tion. Coverage-dependent ESD measurements from NO on Ni(l 11) are shown in fig. 4. From NO on clean Ni(l 11) both 0"'" and NO'1' are observed. The coverage dependence of the O'1" signal is initially similar to that from CO, i.e. the signal increases, peaks at 1 L and then decrases. At 2 L, however, a phase transition occurs which results in a strong enhancement of both the 0"'" and NO"1" signals. A bent-to-linear nitrosyi phase change could, in principle, account for the ob- 534 Volume 125, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 18 April 1986 2 340 12 NO EXPOSURE (LANGMUIR) Fig. 4. (a) The NO exposure dependence of the O'''and NO* ESD signals from NO/Ni(lll) at 90 K, Ey = 400 eV. (b) The NO and 0; exposure dependence of the O* signal from NO/Ni(lll) and Oz/Nidll) at 90 K, respectively, in the presence of 0.25 monolayer of potassium, fg = 400 eV. served change. However, ESDIAD studies [19] indi- cate that at low temperature (80 K) NO is bonded with its axis perpendicular to the nickel surface at all coverages. It is most likely that the phase transition represents a shift in binding site, the strong Nt^ signal indicating that the on-top binding site is populated. Such behavior has been observed by EELS in the case ofNO/Ni(100) [20]. The observed ESD enhancement is a reflection of the reduced neutralization rate in the on-top site. In the presence of K (fig. 4b), no N0"'" could be detected, and as in the case of CO, the 0"*" yield shows a delayed onset versus coverage. To elimi- nate the possibility that this behavior is the result of the dissociation of NO on this surface, we measured the O"*" ESD from an oxygen-exposed, K-modified Ni surface. As can be seen from fig. 4b, the coverage de- pendence of the resulting O"1" ESD is considerably dif- ferent than that of the NO + K/Ni system. As in the case of chemisorbed CO, we ascribe the quenching of the ESD form NO/Ni(l 11) observed at low coverages to the formation of a strongly perturbed, probably tilted NO species. In conclusion, we see that potassium co-adsorption can have a profound effect on excited processes involv- ing electronically excited states at surfaces. This is evidenced in the yields of ions (CO"1", NO'1", O"1", O2"^) produced by electron-stimulated desorption of CO or NO on Ni(l 11), as described above. For a fixed potas- sium surface coverage, the effects depend on the ad- sorbate coverage. At saturation adsorbate coverages the main effect of potassium is to eliminate all ESD activity associated with Ols core ionization. We ten- tatively ascribe this effect to the K-induced metal-to- C0(27r*) strong back-donation in the ground state of adsorbate-surface complex which, upon core ioniza- tion, helps screen the core-hole potential thus reducing the excitation probability of shake-off states respon- sible for the ESD. The ESD studies also provide evi- dence for phase transitions induced by changes in ad- sorbate surface coverage on both the clean and K- modified nickel surface. In particular, at low exposures (<1 L) of the K-modified surface to CO or NO at 90 K, a special adsorbate state is produced, probably a K-adsorbate complex or a tilted CO or NO phase, which is totally ESD inactive at either valence or core-excita- tion energies. Menzel, Surface Sci. 109 (1981) 493. [7] Ph. Avouris, P.S. Bagus and C.J. Nelin, J. Electron Spectry., to be pubBshed. [8] P.S. Bagus, A.R. Rossi and Ph. Avouris, Phys, Rev. B31 (1985)1722. [9] R. [11] J.J. Weimer and E. Umbach,Phys. Rev. B30 (1984) 4863; J.J. Weimer, E. Umbach and D. Menzel, Surface Sci. 155 (1985)132. [12] P.P. Netzer, D.L. Doering and T.E. Phys. 78 (1983) 2998. [17] A.R. Rossi and Ph. Avouris, unpublished results. [18] P.M. Hoffmann and R.A. dePaula, Phys. Rev. Letters 52 (1984) 1697. [19] F.P. Netzer and T.E. Madey, Surface Sci. 110 (1981) 251. [20] Ph. Avouris, N.J. DiNardo and J.E. Demuth, J. Chem. Phys. 80 (1984) 491. 536 ect on excited processes involv- ing electronically excited states at surfaces. This is evidenced in the yields of ions (CO"1", NO'1", O"1", O2"^) produced by electron-stimulated desorption of CO or NO on Ni(l 11), as described above. For a fixed potas- sium surface coverage, the effects depend on the ad- sorbate coverage. At saturation adsorbate coverages the main effect of potassium is to eliminate all ESD activity associated with Ols core ionization. We ten- tatively ascribe this effect to the K-induced metal-to- C0(27r*) strong back-donation in the ground state of adsorbate-surface complex which, upon core ioniza- tion, helps screen the core-hole potential thus reducing the excitation probability of shake-off states respon- sible for the ESD. The ESD studies also provide evi- dence for phase transitions induced by changes in ad- sorbate surface coverage on both the clean and K- modified nickel surface. In particular, at low exposures (<1 L) of the K-modified surface to CO or NO at 90 K, a special adsorbate state is produced, probably a K-adsorbate complex or a tilted CO or NO phase, which is totally ESD inactive at either valence or core-excita- tion energies. head.ce:title: Alkali co-adsorption and surface coverage effects on electron-stimulated desorption (ESD): CO and NO on Ni(111)

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: IBM T.J. Watson Research Center, P.O. Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: We present results on the effect of potassium co-adsorption on the ESD from CO and NO on Ni(111) at 90 K. K co-adsorption strongly affects the yields of positive ions and alters their electron beam energy dependence. At a K-coverage of θK = 0.25 and saturation coverages of CO or NO, the strong O+ ESD threshold associated with O 1s ionization is eliminated. We attribute this to increased metal → CO(2π★) electron back-donation upon K addition which screens the O 1s hole, and reduces the excitation probability of shake-off/shake-up processes responsible for O+ ESD. For fixed K-coverage, the ESD yields depend on adsorbate coverage. For θK = 0.25 and CO or NO exposures <1 L the adsorbate state is ESD inactive at both valence- and core-excitation energies.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: The chemical physics of solid surfaces and heterogeneous catalysis
Metal-support and metal-additive effects in catalysis

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Photoemission and the electronic properties of surfaces
